15.87.text: So, last month, the Encyclopaedia Britannica announced

19.26.text: that it is going out of print

21.01.text: after 244 years, which made me nostalgic,

24.83.text: because I remember playing a game with the colossal encyclopedia set in my hometown library

30.48.text: back when I was a kid,

33.07.text: And I wondered if I could update that game,

40.57.text: I went to an online encyclopedia,

41.87.text: Wikipedia, and I entered the term "Earth."

44.63.text: You can start anywhere, this time I chose Earth.

47.30.text: And the first rule of the game is pretty simple.

49.78.text: You just have to read the article

51.27.text: until you find something you don't know,

53.85.text: and preferably something your dad doesn't even know.

56.96.text: And in this case, I quickly found this:

59.84.text: The furthest point from the center of the Earth

62.13.text: is not the tip of Mount Everest, like I might have thought,

64.61.text: it's the tip of this mountain: Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador.

67.90.text: The Earth spins, of course, as it travels around the sun,

71.42.text: so the Earth bulges a little bit around the middle,

74.53.text: And even though Mount Chimborazo isn't the tallest mountain in the Andes,

79.42.text: it's one degree away from the equator,

81.10.text: it's riding that bulge, and so the summit of Chimborazo

84.10.text: is the farthest point on Earth from the center of the Earth.

87.50.text: And it is really fun to say.

91.39.text: this is going to be the name of the game,

94.77.text: You can use it at TED.

97.07.text: It's like "eureka" and "bingo" had a baby.

103.80.text: So the next rule of the game is also pretty simple.

107.42.text: You just have to find another term and look that up.

110.31.text: Now in the old days, that meant getting out a volume

115.86.text: Nowadays there are hundreds of links to choose from.

118.49.text: I can go literally anywhere in the world,

120.44.text: I think since I was already in Ecuador,

122.17.text: I just decided to click on the word "tropical."

124.88.text: That took me to this wet and warm band of the tropics

131.30.text: Now that's the Tropic of Cancer in the north

133.77.text: and the Tropic of Capricorn in the south,

136.09.text: but I was surprised to learn this little fact:

140.55.text: like latitude or the borders between nations,

144.16.text: they are astronomical phenomena caused by the Earth's tilt,

148.49.text: They move; they go up, they go down.

151.14.text: In fact, for years, the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn

154.34.text: have been steadily drifting towards the equator

156.98.text: at the rate of about 15 meters per year,

162.89.text: So to keep the game going, I just have to find another term and look that one up.

168.66.text: Since I'm already in the tropics, I chose "Tropical rainforest."

172.46.text: Famous for its diversity, human diversity.

174.75.text: There are still dozens and dozens of uncontacted tribes living on this planet.

180.27.text: They're all over the globe, but virtually all of them live in tropical rainforests.

184.75.text: This is the only place you can go nowadays and not get "friended."

189.73.text: The link that I clicked on here was exotic in the beginning and then absolutely mysterious at the very end.

198.59.text: It mentioned leopards and ring-tailed coatis and poison dart frogs and boa constrictors and then

207.29.text: which turn out to be beetles.

210.53.text: Now I clicked on this on purpose,

212.75.text: but if I'd somehow gotten here by mistake,

214.30.text: it does remind me, for the band, see "The Beatles,"

218.01.text: but I am here for beetle beetles.

220.74.text: This is the most successful order on the planet by far.

224.61.text: Something between 20 and 25 percent of all life forms on the planet,

230.67.text: That means the next time you are in the grocery store,

232.85.text: take a look at the four people ahead of you in line.

235.06.text: Statistically, one of you is a beetle.

238.07.text: And if it is you, you are astonishingly well adapted.

243.67.text: There are scavenger beetles that pick the skin and flesh off of bones in museums.

248.70.text: There are predator beetles, that attack other insects

251.78.text: and still look pretty cute to us.

253.57.text: There are beetles that roll little balls of dung

257.07.text: great distances across the desert floor to feed to their hatchlings.

260.37.text: This reminded the ancient Egyptians of their god Khepri,

264.15.text: who renews the ball of the sun every morning,

267.46.text: which is how that dung-rolling scarab

269.49.text: became that sacred scarab on the breastplate of the Pharaoh Tutankhamun.

274.86.text: Beetles, I was reminded, have the most romantic flirtation in the animal kingdom.

280.78.text: Fireflies are not flies, fireflies are beetles.

283.37.text: Fireflies are coleoptera, and coleoptera communicate in other ways as well.

292.99.text: Now the pheromone page took me to a video of a sea urchin having sex.

307.89.text: Now that's something that increases sexual desire,

311.75.text: There is a compound in chocolate called phenethylamine

320.09.text: it's unlikely that phenethylamine will reach your brain if taken orally.

324.26.text: So those of you who only eat your chocolate, you might have to experiment.

327.37.text: The link I clicked on here,

331.18.text: "sympathetic magic," mostly because I understand what both of those words mean.

336.38.text: But not when they're together like that.

338.54.text: I do like sympathy. I do like magic.

341.53.text: So when I click on "sympathetic magic,"

342.87.text: I get sympathetic magic and voodoo dolls.

347.68.text: This is the boy in me getting lucky again.

352.34.text: If you imitate something, maybe you can have an effect on it.

354.75.text: That's the idea behind voodoo dolls, and possibly also cave paintings.

359.18.text: The link to cave paintings takes me to some of the oldest art known to humankind.

364.26.text: I would love to see Google maps inside some of these caves.

369.77.text: Common themes around the globe include large wild animals and tracings of human hands,

377.09.text: We have been a dominantly right-handed tribe for millenia,

381.55.text: so even though I don't know why a paleolithic person would trace his hand

386.89.text: or blow pigment on it from a tube,

388.87.text: I can easily picture how he did it.

391.46.text: And I really don't think it's that different form our own little dominant hand avatar

395.97.text: right there that I'm going to use now to click on the term for "hand,"

399.30.text: go to the page for "hand," where I found the most fun and possibly embarrassing bit of trivia

405.59.text: I've found in a long time. It's simply this:

407.62.text: The back of the hand is formally called the opisthenar.

411.81.text: Now that's embarrassing, because up until now,

415.48.text: every time I've said, "I know it like the back of my hand,"

418.68.text: I've really been saying, "I'm totally familiar with that,

421.04.text: I just don't know it's freaking name, right?"

423.62.text: And the link I clicked on here,

427.28.text: well, lemurs, monkeys and chimpanzees have the little opisthenar.

431.43.text: I click on chimpanzee, and I get our closest genetic relative.

435.68.text: Pan troglodytes, the name we give him, means "cave dweller."

441.18.text: He lives in rainforests and savannas.

443.00.text: It's just that we're always thinking of this guy as lagging behind us,

446.21.text: evolutionarily or somehow uncannily creeping up on us,

449.27.text: and in some cases, he gets places before us.

452.94.text: Like my next link, the almost irresistible link, Ham the Astrochimp.

458.17.text: I click on him, and I really thought he was going to bring me full circle twice, in fact.

463.54.text: which is smack in the middle of my tropics map,

467.30.text: and more specifically his skeleton wound up in the Smithsonian museum getting picked clean by beetles.

473.53.text: In between those two landmarks in Ham's life,

482.25.text: months before the first human being to do it,

487.69.text: When I click on Yuri Gagarin's page,

489.84.text: I get this guy who was surprisingly short in stature,

494.30.text: Top estimates, Soviet estimates, put this guy at 1.65 meters,

498.64.text: that is less than five and a half feet tall max,

501.64.text: possibly because he was malnourished as a child.

506.99.text: A Nazi officer took over the Gagarin household,

510.09.text: and he and his family built and lived in a mud hut.

512.89.text: Years later, the boy from that cramped mud hut

516.44.text: would grow up to be the man in that cramped capsule

519.94.text: on the tip of a rocket

521.56.text: who volunteered to be launched into outer space,

525.05.text: the first one of any of us to really physically leave this planet.

529.40.text: And he didn't just leave it,

533.27.text: Fifty years later, as a tribute,

535.50.text: the International Space Station, which is still up there tonight,

539.42.text: synced its orbit with Gagarin's orbit,

543.50.text: at the exact same time of day,

546.23.text: so you can go online and you can watch over 100 minutes

549.81.text: of what must have been an absolutely mesmerizing ride,

554.46.text: the first person to ever see such a thing.

556.74.text: And then when you've had your fill of that,

558.17.text: you can click on one more link.

560.78.text: You can come back to Earth.

562.13.text: You return to where you started.

566.50.text: You just need to find one more fact that you didn't know.

570.09.text: And for me, I quickly landed on this one:

572.57.text: The Earth has a tolerance of about .17 percent from the reference spheroid,

577.59.text: which is less than the .22 percent allowed in billiard balls.

581.56.text: This is the kind of fact I would have loved as a boy.

585.24.text: It's got some math that I can do.

587.51.text: I'm pretty sure my dad doesn't know it.

589.64.text: What this means is that if you could shrink the Earth to the size of a billiard ball,

595.13.text: if you could take planet Earth, with all its mountain tops and caves

601.14.text: and rainforests, astronauts and uncontacted tribes and chimpanzees, voodoo dolls,

605.82.text: fireflies, chocolate, sea creatures making love in the deep blue sea,

611.34.text: you just shrink that to the size of a billiard ball,

614.55.text: it would be as smooth as a billiard ball,

618.44.text: presumably a billiard ball with a slight bulge around the middle.
